author: apnewjersey
title: Dispute over mailed ballots in NJ county delays primary outcome
text: Dispute over mailed ballots in NJ county delays outcome of congressional primary Whether to count more than 1,900 mail ballots cast in one [New Jersey](https://apnews.com/hub/new-jersey) county will be up to a judge after their envelopes were unsealed prematurely and members of the local election board deadlocked on how to proceed. Superior Court Judge Michael J. Blee will hear arguments Friday in Atlantic City. The decision could affect the outcome of the [Democratic primary](https://apnews.com/article/new-jersey-primary-trump-biden-menendez-kim-00fe6c8c88d64eeeecf8fae73bc67892) in the race for the stateâ€™s 2nd Congressional District, where businessman Joe Salerno holds a 400-vote lead over attorney Tim Alexander in unofficial results. At the center of the dispute is a state law that allows local election officials to open mail ballots five days before an election day. In Atlantic County this year, the envelopes containing the 1,909 ballots were unsealed about a month before Tuesday's primary, but the ballots themselves were not removed at that time, said Creed Pogue, a Democrat appointed to the county Board of Elections. The circumstances that led to the envelopes being unsealed early are in dispute. Democratic officials have described what happened as a mistake, while Republican officials say there are indications it might have been done intentionally to speed up ballot counting. The political and legal wrangling over fewer than 2,000 ballots, while a local dispute, also signals how carefully both parties are paying attention to the voting process this year and how local election offices are [under intense scrutiny](https://apnews.com/article/election-2024-voting-results-certification-trump-09bb9d1fdc11b495b7c50687e5576997). Similar problems surfacing during the November general election, especially if they occur in swing states where the presidential election is likely to be close, are almost certain to draw the attention of national campaigns and parties. Pogue said an error occurred when Atlantic County election workers were implementing a new procedure of adding timestamps to the inner envelopes containing the mail ballots. READ ALSO: [Republicans in NJ pick gay, pro-choice Senate candidate. Can they finally win?](https://nj1015.com/republicans-in-nj-pick-gay-pro-choice-senate-candidate-can-they-finally-win/?utm_source=tsmclip&utm_medium=referral) Previously, timestamps were added only to the outer envelope, which contains no information that identifies the voter. To improve ballot tracking, Pogue said, it was decided that a timestamp also should be added to the inner envelope. But the machine was still programmed to unseal the envelopes when adding the timestamp, Pogue said. At no time were the ballots removed and counted before the five-day window outlined in state law, he said. "Because of no fault of their own, because of an innocent mistake, that should not disenfranchise a voter, particularly when there was no evidence of malicious intent, no evidence of any tampering," Pogue said. â€œWe should, therefore, make sure these ballots are counted and the wishes of the voters known.â€ The board met on Tuesday, with Pogue and the other Democratic member voting for a motion to accept the prematurely opened ballots for counting while the two Republican board members voted against. READ ALSO: [New Jersey Proposes Radical Changes To Discrimination Laws, Impact On Employers](https://nj1015.com/these-are-the-new-work-rules-all-new-jersey-businesses-must-follow/?utm_source=tsmclip&utm_medium=referral) Don Purdy, chair of the Atlantic County Republicans, said he believed the ballots were opened intentionally based on conversations with election workers and the fact that the opening of the inner envelopes continued for several days. If it was a mistake, he said officials would have realized it immediately and stopped the process. Purdy said Republicans want the ballots, which were cast in both the Democratic and Republican primaries, to be counted. But they want an investigation to determine what happened, a plan to ensure it doesnâ€™t happen again and for affected voters to be notified. Purdy said election officials were aware of what happened weeks ago and that public confidence in the election office has suffered as a result. He wants more oversight. â€œIâ€™m not saying to throw these ballots out. Iâ€™m saying the election process was compromised,â€ Purdy said. â€œYou canâ€™t fix something unless you admit there is a problem and fix it.â€ In a court filing Thursday, the state attorney generalâ€™s office noted that state law was silent on what a local board should do if the inner envelopes are opened â€œintentionally or unintentionallyâ€ before the five-day window. The state has asked the judge to break the tie vote by the county board and decide whether the ballots should be accepted or rejected. [Report a correction](mailto:trenton.dme@townsquaremedia.com?subject=Feedback or correction) ðŸ‘ˆ | ðŸ‘‰ [Contact our newsroom](https://nj1015.com/contact-nj-1015-newsroom/) States with best and worst lifetime tax burden [Self Financial](https://www.self.inc/info/life-of-tax/)â€” and just where New Jersey ranks, nationwide. Gallery Credit: Erin Vogt

author: Ipsita Pati
title: Mercury rises by 3.6Â°C, cold wave likely to hit Gurgaon on weekend | Gurgaon News - Times of India
text: GURGAON: The city's minimum temperature, at 8.4 degrees Celsius on Friday, saw a sharp 3.6-degree rise after hitting the season's lowest the previous day. It was 4.6 degrees Celsius on Thursday. The nighttime temperature was a notch above the normal for this time of the season. However, the India Meteorological Department issued a â€˜yellow' alert for a cold wave in the city over the weekend, with temperatures expected to drop significantly. The city has not yet experienced any â€˜cold' days so far this season. An IMD official said, \"With wind from the northwest direction at a velocity of 6 to 10 kmph, the minimum temperature may fall by 1 to 2 degrees.\" The weather is predicted to remain dry across the state. IMD categorises a day as â€˜severely cold' when the maximum temperature drops below the normal by 6.5 degrees Celsius or more. A cold wave is declared when the minimum temperature dips below the normal by four degrees or more or is less than four degrees Celsius. Residents are advised to prepare for the cold wave and take necessary precautions to stay warm and safe during this period.Dr Neeraj Gupta, associate director of pulmonology, respiratory critical care, and sleep medicine at Max Hospital, Gurgaon, said, \"The cold waves are usually dry, and our body works in humidity. So, if you breathe in cold air, it will cause dryness in the throat and nose. Sometimes, it leads to bleeding from the nose and causes severe throat pain. If taken down to the lungs, it causes bronchospasm, exacerbating asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases. Residents must stay indoors whenever possible and keep the room humid. Try to use oil-based heaters.\"

author: Janelle Wang, Christine Ni and Jeremy Carroll
title: â€˜He must be proud of me': Honoring â€˜Grandpa Vicha' 3 years after he was killed
text: Three years later and still no justice. This weekend, family and friends will gather to remember [Vicha Ratanapakdee](https://www.nbcbayarea.com/tag/vicha-ratanapakdee/), the San Francisco man, affectionately known to the community as â€œGrandpa Vicha.â€ The 84-year-old Thai grandfather was violently pushed to the ground on Jan. 28, 2021 while on a walk near his home. Two days later, he died from his injuries. Grandpa Vichaâ€™s death made international news and fueled the national â€œStop Asian Hateâ€ movement. His daughter, Monthanus, never wanted the public spotlight. And, yet, she has pushed forward to get justice for her dad, â€œTurn the grief into bravery â€¦ I would like my dad to be remembered in the civil rights movement nationwide.â€ Three years after his death, there is still no trial date set for Antoine Watson, the man accused in her fatherâ€™s death. Get a weekly recap of the latest San Francisco Bay Area housing news. [Sign up for NBC Bay Areaâ€™s Housing Deconstructed newsletter.] On Sunday, the anniversary of Vicha's attack, an invite-only gathering in San Francisco of community members, including activist Helen Zia and Justin Go, the father of Fremont's Michelle Go who died in 2022 when she was pushed in front of a New York subway. For more details on Sundayâ€™s event in San Francisco, visit [justice4vicha.org](https://www.justice4vicha.org/). A livestream of the event will be held between 2 to 5 p.m.

author: Decatur Daily Democrat
title: Stay Safe with Rambo Total Pest Control's Personalized Protection Plan in Puyallup, WA | News | decaturdailydemocrat.com
text: Puyallup, WA - Rambo Total Pest Control, a family-owned pest control company founded 16 years ago, is dedicated to safeguarding homes in Puyallup, WA, from the threats posed by pests. Recognizing the diverse Puyallup pest management needs across the region; the company offers tailored pest prevention packages to address specific concerns. Rambo Total Pest Control's commitment to personalized solutions ensures that clients receive targeted services, eliminating pests while ensuring they pay only for the necessary treatments. The company's Basic Protection Plan caters to clients dealing with specific pest issues, offering preventive measures to avoid unnecessary expenses for non-existent pest problems. For a comprehensive solution, the Plus Protection Plan provides year-round protection against various pests. Clients opting for this program benefit from eliminating specific pests and enjoy warranties covering a range of other pests. At the top tier, the Advanced Protection Plan provides control and prevention for various pests. This plan is fortified with warrantied protection against a spectrum of pests and includes a limited warranty against Subterranean Termites. The efficiency of this plan is enhanced by re-treatment warranties, ensuring clients receive reliable and long-lasting pest control. Rambo Total Pest Control's array of Pest control Puyallup services covers ants, rodents, stinging insects, spiders, bed bugs, termites, cockroaches, pantry pests, and wood-boring beetles. The company extends its expertise to commercial properties, serving multi-unit housing, property management companies, warehouses, storage facilities, offices, and various business settings. Its commercial pest control service aids businesses in maintaining their reputation, protecting properties, and complying with health and safety regulations. â€œWhen you call, our friendly office staff will discuss with you the specifics of your pest issue, provide an estimated phone quote based on this conversation, and schedule a time for one of our highly trained technicians to come by for the initial inspection and service.â€ said owner, Luke Rambo. For top-notch pest control solutions, Rambo Total Pest Control stands as the trusted choice for homes and businesses in Puyallup, WA. About Rambo Total Pest Control Rambo Total Pest Control, a leading player in the pest control industry, is renowned for its innovative and effective approaches. Founded 16 years ago, the company prioritizes client satisfaction and employee empowerment, regularly training its staff on certified products and the latest techniques. Rambo Total Pest Control is also a proud member of the Washington State Pest Management Association. Media Contact Company Name Rambo Total Pest Control Contact Name Luke Rambo Phone (253) 848-6000 Address 4117 S Meridian Ste A City Puyallup State WA Postal Code 98373 Country United States Website https://rambopest.com/
